bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William Crawford Gorgas, August 26, 1916

div1.p: Carter reports on yellow fever in Colombia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William Crawford Gorgas, August 26, 1916
div1.opener:
C
Barranquilla, Colombia,
August 26, 1916.
General William C. Gorgas,
Chairman,
Yellow Fever Commission.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following report on
some sanitary aspects of the city of Barranquilla, Colombia, and
their relations with the sanitary conditions of the other towns
on the north coast of Colombia. This report is to be considered
in connection with the one submitted by Dr. Guiteras, and is
complementary thereto.

Our direct examination was confined to
Barranquilla. On account of the schedule of
the transportation lines fourteen days more would have been ex-
pended had we done the same for Cartagena, or Santa Marta. We
judged this delay inadvisable as, on account of the inter-communi-
cation between them, a careful examination of the sanitary condi-
tions of Barranquilla would in our opinion be sufficient to show
the sanitary condition of the other two towns.

With Cartagena it is in communication once a
week by a vessel of the United Fruit Company
from Cartagena, and three times a week, both ways, via Calamar.
By this last route the bulk of the passengerstraffic comes. With
Santa Marta there is communication nine times a week by a line of
steam launches. There is considerable passenger traffic from
both places - Cartagena and Santa Marta - so much that it is not
conceivable that there should be yellow fever in either town for
2
any considerable time, in years, without conveyance of the
infection to Barranquilla.

Susceptible people
in Barranquilla.

Also, if yellow fever existed in Barranquilla
its existence should be shown there more
readily than in either Cartagena or Santa Marta. It is a much
larger town than either of the others and it has proportionately
a much larger foreign resident population, a number of whom are
susceptible to yellow fever. Dr. Oscar Noguera, the Departmental
Health Officer, estimates this population at 3,000, but a large
number of them are old residents and immune to yellow fever. It
is the gateway through which passes the great bulk of the passenger
traffic between the plateau and the sea. This is considerable in
amount and is practically all susceptible to yellow fever. Barran-
quilla is the place of stopping to await the steamers going both ways.

There is thus, we think, a sufficient number of people in
Barranquilla susceptible to yellow fever to give an index of its
existence if it does exist there, certainly many more than in
Cartagena or Santa Marta.

Why the other two
towns were not
examined.

On both counts then; that if yellow fever existed
in Santa Marta or Cartagena for any considerable
time it would certainly have infected Barranquilla
also and that it would be more readily found in Barranquilla if it
existed there than in either of the other two towns, we decided to
confine our investigations to Barranquilla, as this shows the sanitary
condition of the other two towns also. We were thus enabled to
make this examination thoroughly, which had not been possible if we
3
had attempted to examine all three towns in the time at our
disposal, and to spend fourteen days longer in doing this seemed
not justified.

Deductions from
examination.

From the findings of our examination as shown
by the report of Dr. Guiteras, we believe that
yellow fever has not existed in Barranquilla since 1911, and the
same statement should apply to Santa Marta and Cartagena. This
may well be due to the removal of the Panama focus. It is stated
that there has been none since 1905.

Communication with
ports to eastward.

In this connection it is to be noted that these
ports receive very few vessels from the ports
of Venezuela and other ports to the eastward, nearly all vessels
going from west to east, and would be little apt to receive in-
fection from themse parts if they were infected. At present the quar-
antine at Puerto Colombia is an added protection against those
ports, which are listed by the quarantine officer as infected with
yellow fever. We inspected this station and find it sufficiently
equipped and working under good regulations.

One case of yellow fever is reported as entering Barranquilla
from the Altrato Valley in 1910, sick on arrival, from which there
was no spread.

I would also invite your attention to the scarcity of
stegomyia (Aëdes calopus), in Barranquilla during our
visit of eight days. Why this should be so is not at first apparent.
There is an intermittent water-supply, although an abundant one when
running. The water is turned off each day from 2 p.m. to 2 a.m.
4
This naturally leads to stowage of water. Yet stegomyia
were certainly scarce. We saw none in flight, but developed
two from a collection of larvae from the American Consulate.
There were about 60 larvae in the collection and only 3 of
them - 2 of which developed - were stegomyia Culex fatigans
(quinquefasciatus) were more common, but not abundant.

Possibly this condition is temporary, as breeding may be
greater during the dry season than at present, and indeed it
may not be general over the town, as I could examine but a few
places. In them there were not 3% of what would have been
found in Panama in 1904. I think, however, that stegomyia are
normally not abundant, the breeding conditions being really
less favorable than seemed to be the case at first sight.

(1) The water tanks in many of the houses of the better
class are closed iron tanks with affluent and effluent pipes.
I am informed that this is generally the case.

(2) Stowage being only from day to day the containers are
fewer and much more often emptied than when water is scarce and
rain water is depended on. In only a small section of the town
is rain water stowed. Indeed, I saw no arrangement for stowing
any. It is worth noting that the only stegomyiae found were
from larvae in rain water in an old bowl set in the earth in the
yard of the Consulate, hence not subject to emptying.

The general concensus of statement of residents was that
stegomyiae were rare, as were any other day feeding mosquitoes
at any time of the year.

Since the finding is that yellow fever does not exist in
the Atlantic ports of Colombia it is scarcely necessary to say
5
that it is not recommended that the Foundation undertake any
work for the elimination of that disease from said ports. It
is, however, advisable for the local authorities to take all
such measures as are necessary and practicable to lessen the
production of stegomyia so as to obviate the danger of a spread
of yellow fever if it be introduced. The susceptible population
in Barranquilla is increasing yearly and will ultimately reach
a point, if this has not already been attained, at which even
with the present small number of stegomyia, the disease will
spread if introduced.

It is to obviate this danger that Dr. Vengoechea proposes
to undertake an anti-stegomyia campaign.

I would add that we received every possible aid in our in-
vestigations from Dr. Vengoechea, the sanitary officer of the
Atlantic coast of Colombia, through whose courtesy we also visited
the quarantine station of Puerto Colombia. We were very favor-
ably impressed with the sincerity, ability and force of this officer.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, H. R. Carter
Member, Yellow Fever Commission.
